newsitem.title: UK: OPTIONS-Bund vols ease after FOMC, but underpinned.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS-Bund vols ease after FOMC, but underpinned.

text.p: LIFFE Bund options' volatilities eased back on Wednesday, trimming recent gains, after the U.S. Federal Reserve's decision on Tuesday to hold rates steady.
The Fed's inaction has moved the spotlight onto the July meeting of the U.S. Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) when traders said interest rates are almost certain to be hiked.
This prospect kept Bund vols relatively underpinned.

Options activity centred around the expiry on Thursday of the June contract on June futures as players covered positions established on the possibility of a U.S. rate rise. Some cashed in on profits racked up on Tuesday when vols spiked up.
"There has been heavy trading in out-of-the-money Bund puts and calls on the June," said a salesman at a European bank in London.
Most active June strikes were 101.50, 102.00 and 102.50. By 1400 GMT, the June Bund future on LIFFE was at 101.42, down 20 basis points.

Some players took profits realised through gamma trades that featured heavily in recent days. These involved buying out-of-the-money calls and puts based on a forecast of a sharp movement in the underlying Bunds.
"We had the sharp move so the gamma has worked," said the salesman.
Gamma is the measure of the rate of change in the delta of the underlying asset price.

The implied volatility on the July options on September Bund futures at the 101.00 strike traded at 5.30 percent compared with a close of 5.59 percent on Tuesday. August options, also on September futures, were trading down slightly at 5.39 percent.
"It's coming off marginally but not as much as one would have thought," said the salesman.

Vols should continue to dip, but less so on forward contracts such as August which reflects the prospect of a future U.S. rate hike, he said. July should find good support just above the 5.00 percent level.
"It's still a bit of a bearish market," said a trader at a U.S house. "But if it moves back down drastically a lot of locals will come back, pushing vols higher."
Traders recommended short term strategies ahead of the next Fed meeting, such as a put spread at 100.00/99.00 strikes. This should take into account further possible slides in Bunds.
